Fig. 9 Toward non-precious nanocomposite photocatalyst: An efficient ternary photoanode TiO2 nanotube/Co9S8/polyoxometalate for photoelectrochemical water splitting Ran Liu Zhixia Sun ⁎ Xixi Song Yuzhuo Zhang Lin Xu ⁎ Lu Xi Key Laboratory of Polyoxometalate Science of Ministry of Education, Department of Chemistry, Northeast Normal University, Changchun, Jilin 130024, PR China Key Laboratory of Polyoxometalate Science of Ministry of Education Department of Chemistry Northeast Normal University Changchun Jilin 130024 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The TiO2 nanotubes/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode shows an 8.5-fold improvement in photocurrent density compared to the TiO2 nanotubes photoanode in the photoelectrochemical water oxidation. At present the photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting achieves a very high efficiency, but the development of the efficient and inexpensive photoanode materials is still desired for practical application. Herein, we fabricate a composite photoanode consisting of TiO2 nanotube arrays modified with polyoxometalate (POM) and Co9S8, in which POM aims to facilitate charge separation and Co9S8 acts as good electron transport mediator. It is the first introduction of Co9S8 into PEC water oxidation system. Although these three components are all non-precious inorganic materials, the photocurrent density of the TiO2/Co9S8/POM composite photoanode reaches up to 1.12mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs RHE under simulated solar light illumination, which is among the highest PEC water oxidation photoanodes. Particularly, the TiO2/Co9S8/POM composite photoanode shows an 8.5-fold improvement in photocurrent density compared to the pristine TiO2 nanotube array photoanode. The measurements of EIS and Mott-Schottky plots revealed that the TiO2/Co9S8/POM composite photoanode held the best efficiency of charge separation and transport at the interface as well as the highest carrier density. The aforementioned results demonstrate a feasible approach to improving the PEC water splitting efficiency by dual modification of TiO2 nanotube arrays with low-cost materials. Keywords TiO2 nanotube arrays Polyoxometalates Co9S8 Photoelectrochemical Water oxidation 1 Introduction Photoelectrochemical water splitting into oxygen and hydrogen has been one of the most promising and sustainable strategies for solar energy conversion and storage [1–4]. Since Fujishima and Honda published the first photoelectrochemical cell of water splitting using TiO2 photoanodes [5], TiO2 has become a preponderant candidate of photoanode materials in photoelectrochemical water splitting due to its chemical inertness, photostability, nontoxicity and low cost [6–10]. In particular, one-dimensional nanostructure TiO2 such as nanotube arrays has received considerable attention because of its high surface area and one-dimensional nanostructure which is favorable to charge transport and relatively efficient charge separation [11,12]. Furthermore, such one-dimensional TiO2 nanotube array photoanode could provide a convenient diffusion pathway of photogenerated holes to the electrode/electrolyte interface, which is the key step in the photoelectrochemical water oxidation system. However, the photoelectrochemical water splitting efficiency of pristine TiO2 nanotubes is still unsatisfactory in practical applications; this is mainly because the pristine TiO2 materials suffer from the limited solar light absorption (wide band gap) and the fast photogenerated electron-hole recombination [13]. Many efforts have been made to extend visible-light utilization by doping, dye sensitization and so on. Another critical challenge for improving the water splitting efficiency is how to boost charge separation and transfer as well as retard the fast electron-hole recombination in TiO2 photoanode [14]. Thus, an effective strategy is to develop TiO2-based composite materials by incorporating with functional additive, which can suppress the charge recombination and promote photogenerated charge transfer. But the present availability of the functional additives is still restricted to a minority of materials such as noble metals, graphene, carbon quantum dot and special semiconductors. Hence it is greatly necessary to explore new functional additives for effectively improving TiO2 photoanode that can reduce the charge recombination and facilitate the photogenerated charge transfer. Polyoxometalates (POMs), a class of molecular metal-oxo cluster compounds based mainly on Mo, W, and V, have shown superior physicochemical properties and various applications in catalysis, materials science and medicine [15,16]. Especially, POMs have an intrinsic characteristic to be an efficient electron acceptor [17–20], which could capture the photogenerated electrons from semiconductors and then transport the electrons to the neighboring domain. Ozer and Ferry previously investigated the use of POMs in TiO2 suspensions to increase the photocatalytic efficiency of 1,2-dichlorobenzene [21]. Our group reported a series of researches on the POMs-TiO2 nanocomposite photoanodes, which demonstrated a remarkable improvement in photoelectrochemical or photoconductive performance in comparison with pristine TiO2 nanoparticles [22–24]. Although POMs could act as an efficient electron acceptor to facilitate the exciton separation as well as retard the fast charge recombination, POMs belong to high electric resistance materials that is disadvantageous to electron transport. Therefore, we consider to find a proper material with excellent electrical conductivity for synergistically improving the photoelectrochemical performance of TiO2 nanotubes. Recently, Co9S8 has attracted much attention due to its super electrochemical performance and applications in a variety of fields such as supercapacitors, lithium-ion batteries, dye-sensitized solar cells, hydrogen evolution and oxygen reduction reaction [25–28]. Particularly, Co9S8 exhibits intrinsically metallic or conductive behavior, together with its better stability than metals in specific environments and conditions, implying the possibility of using Co9S8 as a fine electron transport mediator [29,30]. Clearly, the good electron transport in the photoanode could indirectly increase the amount of free holes, which is a favorable condition for photoelectrochemical water oxidation. These aforementioned results motivated us to explore a new avenue of improving the photoelectrochemical water oxidation performance by means of modifying TiO2 nanotube arrays (TNAs) with POM and Co9S8; this arouses a rational design of TNAs/Co9S8/POM ternary composite photoanode. Evidently, such a composite photoanode can endow with the following advantages: (1) The one-dimensional TiO2 nanotube arrays afford short carrier-diffusion paths along the tube walls, decreasing charge losses due to grain boundary resistance. (2) POMs can facilitate the exciton separation as well as retard electron-hole recombination, behaving as “shallow electron trap”. (3) Co9S8 has good electrical conductivity similar to metallic behavior. Thus we consider that the ternary composite photoanode may contribute their respective advantages to the photoelectrochemical performance, so that a high efficiency of photoelectrochemical water oxidation could be predicted. However, to our best knowledge, there are no reports on the synergetic effects of polyoxometalate and Co9S8 on TiO2 nanotube photoanode for photoelectrochemical water oxidation. Herein, we report the fabrication of the nanocomposite photoanode consisting of TiO2 nanotubes, polyoxometalate ((Bu4N)3PW12O40, denoted as PW12) and Co9S8, in which PW12 aims to facilitate charge separation and Co9S8 acts as good electron transport mediator. Meanwhile, the use of TiO2 nanotube arrays on titanium foil as photoanode decreases a back-contact interface (FTO/TiO2) that may be a charge recombination site. Although Co9S8 has well been utilized in photocatalytic, electrocatalytic and energy storage devices, this is the first attempt to introduce Co9S8 into a photoelectrochemical water oxidation system. For the TiO2/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode, the photocurrent density at 1.23V (vs. RHE) and the maximum photoconversion efficiency exhibited an 8.5-fold and a 7-fold improvements in the photoelectrochemical water oxidation, respectively, in comparison with the pristine TiO2 nanotubes photoanode. The remarkable improvement in the efficiency of photoelectrochemical water oxidation is mainly attributed to both the effective charge separation from PW12 and the favorable electron transport from Co9S8. The measurements of EIS and Mott-Schottky plots revealed that the TiO2/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode held the best efficiency of charge separation and charge transport at the interface as well as the highest carrier density, as compared to the three control photoanodes (TiO2/PW12, TiO2/Co9S8 and TiO2). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials TiO2 nanotube arrays (TNAs) were prepared according to the literature method via a two-step anodization of Ti foils (0.15mm thickness, 99.7% purity) in an ethylene glycol electrolyte (containing 0.5wt.% NH4F and 3 vol% water) at room temperature, with an applied potential of 60V by using a computer controlled sourcemeter (Model 2400, Keithley, USA) [31,32]. The TNAs/Co9S8 film was fabricated by the solvothermal method reported previously by Feng et al. [33]. In a typical procedure, 5mmol cobalt (II) acetate tetrahydrate and 5mmol thiourea were dissolved in 30mL ethylene glycol and vigorously stirred to uniformity. Then, the resulting solution was moved into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (40mL) together with the as-prepared TNAs film and maintained at 200°C in an oven for 8h. After cooling down to room temperature, the TNAs/Co9S8 film photoanode was washed with deionized water and ethanol for 3 times, respectively, and finally dried at 60°C for 3h. The tetrabutylammonium salt of Keggin-type polyoxometalate (Bu4N)3PW12O40 was synthesized according to literature method [34], and deposited on the TNAs/Co9S8 film photoanode by using the successive ionic layer adsorption and reaction (SILAR) method assisted with sonication [35]. In the SILAR process, the TNAs/Co9S8 film photoanode was sequentially dipped in the beakers containing 1mmol PW12 aqueous and 3mmol tetrabutylammonium bromide aqueous in turn for at least 1min each dipping with sonication (50W, 60kHz). The TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 film photoanode was prepared after 8 circles. 2.2 Experiments for PEC water splitting Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting measurements were carried out in a quartz cell using the three-electrode system with an Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode in a 0.5M Na2SO4 electrolyte. A 300W xenon lamp with light intensity of 100mW/cm2 (AM 1.5G) served as the light source to simulate the sunlight. 2.3 General characterization All the photoelectrochemical experiments were recorded on a CHI660C Electrochemical Workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Corporation, China) at room temperature. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was measured at open circuit voltage with an ac bias signal of 10mV in the frequency range 10−1–105 Hz under Xe lamp with light intensity of 100mW/cm2 (AM 1.5G) irradiance. UV electronic spectra were obtained on a Varian Cary 50 Conc UV–vis spectrophotometer. The crystallization behavior was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (D/max 2200 VPC diffract meter with a Cu Kα irradiation source). The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) measurements were performed by an Axis Ultra spectrometer (Kratos Analytical Ltd., England) with Al Ka radiation source. The binding energies were normalized to the signal for adventitious carbon at 284.6eV. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (SU-8010, Hitachi) equipped with an energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) was employed for characterization of the morphology, structural variations of the samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of TNAs, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composites Fig. 1 illustrates the SEM images of the TNAs, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composites. Fig. 1A shows the top view of the TiO2 nanotube arrays, with the pore diameter of tubular structure around 100nm. The TNAs/Co9S8 composites are hydrothermally synthesized and TNAs are fully covered with interconnected nanoflakes of Co9S8. The TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite (Fig. 1C) appears in the highly open and exposed porous nanotube arrays, in which both Co9S8 and PW12 are uniformly deposited on the edge of each TiO2 nanotube orifice. In order to confirm the existence of PW12 in the composite film, EDS measurement was carried out to analyze the elemental composition of the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite film. The EDS of the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite film exhibits strong diffraction peaks of element Ti at 4.51 and 4.92 keV, and three peaks of elements Co and S are clearly observed at 6.82, 7.71 and 2.25 keV. While the diffraction peaks of elements P and O appear at 1.89 and 0.52 keV, element W displays four peaks at 1.82, 2.15, 8.38 and 9.62 keV. These data demonstrated the existence of Co, S, P and W, which indicated that the Co9S8 and PW12 were successfully introduced into the TiO2 nanotube array photoanode. The cross-sectional SEM image of the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanode is shown in Fig. 1E, which shows the average thickness of TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanode is 13.4μm. X-ray diffraction patterns of TNAs, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composites are shown in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2a, the diffraction peaks along (101), (004), (200), (331) and (420) lattice planes feature the crystal structure of anatase for the TiO2 nanotube arrays [36,37]. The characteristic peaks in Fig. 2b are assigned to the (111), (311), (331), (511), (440), and (533) lattice planes, respectively, which are indexed as cobalt pentlandite (i.e. Co9S8; JCPDS, No. 65-6801) [38]. This result reveals that Co9S8 is indeed grown on the TNAs. The strong and sharp diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns demonstrate that the Co9S8 are well crystallized [39]. The XRD pattern of TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 is very similar to that of the TNAs/Co9S8, suggesting that the introduction of PW12 into the composite did not affect the crystal structure of TNAs and Co9S8. Moreover, no diffraction peak of PW12 is observed in XRD patterns of the composite, which may be due to the amorphous state of trace PW12. To further identify the chemical composition of TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composites, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements were carried out. Fig. 3 A shows the survey XPS spectra of the TNAs, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 samples. The peak at 790eV refers to Co 2p. After the subtraction of a Shirley background followed by fitting with a mixture function of Lorentzian and Gaussian, the Co 2p peak can be mainly deconvoluted into two spin-orbit doublets and two shake-up satellites (donated as sat.), in which the two main peaks are located at 781.1eV and 797.4eV, assigned to the spin-orbit splitting value of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively. The peaks at 161.4eV and 162.5eV can be assigned to the S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 binding energies of S2− in Co9S8, with a split of 1.1eV. These are in good agreement with the previous report [40]. After adding the POMs into the TNAs/Co9S8 composites, the presence of W element in the film can be confirmed by observed signal peaks in the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite films in Fig. 3A and 3D [41]. The characteristic peaks located at 35.1eV and 36.1eV can be assigned to the W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2, respectively. These results prove the incorporation of Co9S8 and PW12 into the TiO2 nanotube array photoanode. 3.2 UV–vis reflection spectra Fig. 4 A displays the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of TNAs, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composites. All the samples exhibit strong absorption in the UV region, which indicates that these composites exhibit light-harvesting capabilities at the UV region. Further, the band gap energies (Eg) were calculated in the light of the Tauc plot as the intercept value of the plot of (αhν)2 against photon energy (E) [42]. By fitting the linear region of the (αhν)2 to the photon energy-axis (hν) intercept as shown in Fig. 4B, the band gap energies (Eg) of the TNAs, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composites are estimated to be 3.2eV, 3.1eV and 3.0eV, respectively. 3.3 Electrochemical behaviors of TNAs, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composites Photoelectrochemical (PEC) measurements were performed to evaluate the PEC water oxidation activities of the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode. Fig. 5 A shows the linear sweep voltammetry curves of the pristine TiO2, the TNAs/PW12 photoanode, the TNAs/Co9S8, and the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanode under simulated solar light illumination in 0.5M Na2SO4 aqueous solution. The photocurrent densities of all the samples are enhanced with increasing positive bias voltage. The pristine TiO2 photoanode displays the low photocurrents of 0.131mA/cm2 at 1.23V (vs. RHE) and 0.225mA/cm2 at 1.6V (vs. RHE), the TNAs/PW12 photoanode displays photocurrents of 0.282mA/cm2 at 1.23V (vs. RHE) and 0.341mA/cm2 at 1.6V (vs. RHE), while the photocurrents of the TiO2/Co9S8 photoanode (0.462mA/cm2 at 1.23V and 0.565mA/cm2 at 1.6V) are higher than that of the TiO2 and TNAs/PW12 photoanode. Remarkably, the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode exhibits the highest photocurrents of 1.12mA/cm2 at 1.23V and 1.48mA/cm2 at 1.6V among those samples. Especially, the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanode shows an 8.5-fold (at 1.23V) improvement in photocurrent density, as compared to the pristine TiO2 photoanode. Moreover, it can be observed from Fig. 5A that the onset potential of the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanode shifts negatively as compared to that of the pristine TiO2 photoanode; this implies that the ternary composite materials possess lower band bend requirement for photogenerated charge carriers separation [43,44]. The aforementioned data clearly demonstrate that the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode has a superior performance of PEC water oxidation. In addition, the photoconversion efficiency (η) of a photoanode is generally used to evaluate its PEC water splitting performance. For these four photoanodes, their photoconversion efficiency can be calculated via the following equation [45,46]: (1) η = I ( 1.23 − V ) / J light where V is the applied voltage versus RHE, I is the photocurrent density at the measured potential, and Jlight is the irradiance intensity. Fig. 5B presents the plots of the η value versus applied potential. The maximum η values of the pristine TiO2 photoanode, the TNAs/PW12 photoanode, the TNAs/Co9S8 photoanode and the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode are 0.08%, 0.15%, 0.26% and 0.56%, respectively. Obviously, the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode shows the highest η value than other samples, which is accordance with the linear sweep voltammetry results. These results further demonstrate that the introduction of PW12 and Co9S8 into TiO2 nanotubes photoanode could effectively improve the PEC water splitting performance. To further explore the PEC performance of these samples, the photocurrent response measurements were carried out at a constant bias voltage of 1.23V (vs. RHE). As shown in Fig. 6 , all the samples containing the pristine TiO2 photoanode, the TNAs/PW12 photoanode, the TNAs/Co9S8 photoanode and the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode represent fast, steady and reproducible anodic photocurrent responses when the irradiation is switched on and off. The pristine TiO2 photoanode displays the least photocurrent, distinctly resulting from the fast charge pair recombination in the TiO2. However, the TNAs/PW12 photoanode shows the higher photocurrent than the TiO2 photoanode, which indicates that PW12 can be considered as an efficient electron capturer to promote the charge separation in TiO2. Since the photocurrent increase closely depends on the charge transfer status, PW12 should be responsible for the enhanced photocurrent response because of its ability to restrain electron-hole recombination and facilitate photogenerated electron transfer in TiO2. In addition, the TNAs/Co9S8 photoanode also exhibits a stronger photocurrent response than the TiO2 photoanode. Co9S8 can exhibit intrinsically metallic or conductive behavior to promote the interfacial electron transfer, thus leading to the enhanced photocurrent response. It is noteworthy that the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanode exhibits the highest photocurrent response which more exceeds the sum of photocurrent responses of the TNAs/PW12 and the TNAs/Co9S8 photoanodes, suggesting the occurrence of the synergistic effects from both PW12 and Co9S8. To investigate the mechanism of the enhanced PEC water oxidation performance for the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements on these samples were carried out in the frequency range of 1×10−1–1×105 Hz under illumination. It is well-known that EIS measurement could reveal the microscopic situation of charge separation and transport at the interface between the photoanode and the electrolyte solution, so that the charge transfer resistance (Rct) value can be estimated via analyzing the arc radius of the Nyquist plot at the high frequency region. Fig. 7 presents typical Nyquist plots of the pristine TiO2, the TNAs/PW12 photoanode, the TNAs/Co9S8 and the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanodes, and the corresponding equivalent circuit is illustrated in the inset of Fig. 7. As observed from Fig. 7, the arc radius of the TNAs/PW12 photoanode is smaller than that of the pristine TiO2 photoanode, suggesting that the incorporation of PW12 into TiO2 photoanode can enhance the photogenerated electron-hole pair separation as well as facilitate the charge transport. The TNAs/Co9S8 photoanode also shows the smaller charge transfer resistance than the TiO2 photoanode; this should be attributed to the improved conductivity and electron mobility by incorporating with Co9S8. Remarkably, the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanode exhibits the smallest arc radius in the Nyquist plot; this is evident that the ternary composite photoanode possesses the best efficiency of charge separation and transport at the interface between the photoanode and the electrolyte solution, which is a favorable condition for boosting photoelectrochemical water oxidation performance. The above result benefits from the synergistic effects of PW12 and Co9S8 on TiO2 nanotube array photoanode, in which PW12 has the ability to capture the photogenerated electron and Co9S8 has an excellent electrical conductivity. Therefore, the rational modification of TiO2 nanotube array photoanode by both PW12 and Co9S8 should be of effective strategy for enhancing the PEC water splitting performance. 3.4 Mott-Schottky plots To further explore the band structures of all the photoanodes, we measured their Mott-Schottky plots at 5kHz in the dark to investigate the type of semiconductor, flat band potential (EFB) and carrier density (ND) of all these samples based on the following formula: [47,48] (2) 1 C 2 = 2 N D e ε 0 ε ( E − E F B − k T e ) where e is the electron charge, ε is the relative permittivity of the semiconductor, ε0 the permittivity of vacuum (8.85×10−12 N1− C2 m−2),ND is the donor density, E is the electrode applied potential, EFB is the flat band potential, T is the temperature, and k is the Boltzmann constant. As shown in Fig. 8 , the Mott-Schottky plots of all these samples show the positive slopes, indicating the n-type semiconductors characteristic of electrons as the majority carriers. Moreover, the plots are extrapolated to 1/C2 =0 to determine the values of EFB for the TNAs, TNAs/PW12, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanodes, showing almost the same EFB value. The carrier density (ND) can be calculated from the Mott-Schottky plots according to the following formula: [49,50] (3) N D = 2 ε ε 0 e ( d E d ( 1 / C 2 ) ) the ND values of the TNAs, TNAs/PW12, TNAs/Co9S8, and TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanodes are calculated to be 3.63×1017, 9.46×1017, 1.42×1018 and 4.07×1018 cm−3, respectively. The highest electron density of the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 photoanodes implies that the assembly of POMs and Co9S8 could not only facilitate the photogenerated electron separation and transfer, but also improve the PEC water oxidation performance of TiO2 nanotube array, being in well accord with their photoelectrochemical performances. Furthermore, we proposed an action mechanism of the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode considering their energy band positions, as illustrated in Fig. 9 . The conduction band (CB) edge of TiO2 (ECB =−0.5V) is higher than that of PW12 (ECB =0.22V) and the valence band (VB) of Co9S8 (EVB =−0.015V) [51–53]. On one hand, the photogenerated electrons in the CB of TiO2 could be rapidly injected into the CB of PW12. On the other hand, under both the light irradiation and the applied bias potential, the photoexcited electrons could easily transition from the VB to the CB of Co9S8 because of its narrow bandgap (Eg =0.89eV); this motivates the existent holes of Co9S8 to accept the electrons from the TiO2. From the above two aspects, PW12 and Co9S8 on TiO2 nanotube photoanode could synergistically affect the electrons transfer and further improve the charge separation, thereby inducing more holes to participate in photoelectrochemical water oxidation. Consequently, the TNAs/PW12/Co9S8 composite photoanode with favorable energy band matching facilitates the charge separation and transport as well as decreases electron-hole recombination, and then the synergistic effects lead to that the PEC water oxidation performance of the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode is remarkably higher than that of the TNAs/PW12 photoanode and the TNAs/Co9S8 photoanode. 4 Conclusions In summary, using non-precious inorganic materials, we prepared the TNAs/Co9S8/PW12 composite photoanode for the PEC water oxidation and then demonstrated its enhanced performance in comparison with the TNAs, TNAs/Co9S8 and TNAs/PW12 electrodes. The photocurrent density of the ternary composite photoanode is 1.12mA/cm2 (at 1.23V vs. RHE), and the photoconversion efficiency is 0.56%, which display an 8.5-fold and a 7-fold improvements, respectively, compared to that of the pristine TiO2 nanotubes. We believe that the remarkable improvements in the PEC water oxidation performance benefit from the synergistic effects of the facilitated charge separation from PW12 and the favorable electron transport from Co9S8, which could also be demonstrated by the photocurrent response measurements of the composite photoanode and those control photoanodes. The EIS measurement revealed that the ternary composite photoanode held the best efficiency of charge separation and transport at the interface, and the results from Mott-Schottky plots indicated that the ternary composite photoanode has the highest carrier density. This work represents a new insight to improve the PEC water oxidation efficiency by dual modification of TiO2 nanotube arrays with low-cost materials. coredata.dc:description: At present the photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting achieves a very high efficiency, but the development of the efficient and inexpensive photoanode materials is still desired for practical application. Herein, we fabricate a composite photoanode consisting of TiO2 nanotube arrays modified with polyoxometalate (POM) and Co9S8, in which POM aims to facilitate charge separation and Co9S8 acts as good electron transport mediator. It is the first introduction of Co9S8 into PEC water oxidation system. Although these three components are all non-precious inorganic materials, the photocurrent density of the TiO2/Co9S8/POM composite photoanode reaches up to 1.12mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs RHE under simulated solar light illumination, which is among the highest PEC water oxidation photoanodes. Particularly, the TiO2/Co9S8/POM composite photoanode shows an 8.5-fold improvement in photocurrent density compared to the pristine TiO2 nanotube array photoanode. The measurements of EIS and Mott-Schottky plots revealed that the TiO2/Co9S8/POM composite photoanode held the best efficiency of charge separation and transport at the interface as well as the highest carrier density. The aforementioned results demonstrate a feasible approach to improving the PEC water splitting efficiency by dual modification of TiO2 nanotube arrays with low-cost materials.
coredata.dc:title: Toward non-precious nanocomposite photocatalyst: An efficient ternary photoanode TiO2 nanotube/Co9S8/polyoxometalate for photoelectrochemical water splitting
